title: Stars Reach: Jungle World, Desert World, and More Play Test Time
description: I think it is a pretty good sign that I continue to feel that the 2 hour sessions are not enough time to even begin to explore the bounds of what the Stars Reach team has up for us on the play tests so far, and the test this past weekend only built on that […]
author: Wilhelm Arcturus
excerpt: I think it is a pretty good sign that I continue to feel that the 2 hour sessions are not enough time to even begin to explore the bounds of what the Stars Reach team has up for us on the play test…
text: I think it is a pretty good sign that I continue to feel that the 2 hour sessions are not enough time to even begin to explore the bounds of what the Stars Reach team has up for us on the play tests so far, and the test this past weekend only built on that feeling. Stars Reach Announced That said, I was in a bit of a mood going into the weekend’s test as I had been in a weekday session that was the same parameters as the last big weekend test and it did not go well for me.  I had decided I was going to figure out gathering resources and crafting, so as the test opened I headed straight to the portal and went into space to harvest resources, that being the easiest location… according to some… for a number critical materials. Unfortunately right now there is a problem where, when mining through the crust of an asteroid, it is pretty easy to get yourself into an untenable state in a cave of hole and the game just declares you dead instantly. Another asteroid mining death That happened a half a dozen times to me in short order, including twice just trying to get close enough to my corpse to retrieve my stuff, such that I decided I needed a break from that.  As it was, my goal was to craft the grav mesh and you have to unlock the recipe, so I went back through the portal to collect survey locations to get enough points to unlock the recipe.  On doing that I found myself short on a couple of items and clearly needed to go back to space. However, in the mean time somebody decided it would be great to turn the ground around the portal to lava so nobody could use it. I said we’d get to this story, right? Welcome to the sandbox.  I quit the game and went off to do something else at that point.  Some people are going to be jerks just because they can and I was already frustrated about all the asteroid mining deaths. That feeling lingered and I considered giving Saturday a miss, however there was the promise of new things.  New things make pre-alpha fun. The test notes indicated that the multiple planet test would now include multiple planets.  In addition to the temperate planet we had been testing on, Rodin IV so named, we would be getting a desert planet named Zaraxa and a jungle planet named Gaiamar. Also, there would be some new stuff in the skill trees. The skill trees available for the test Those included civil engineers, which allowed for building things. Civil Engineering Also forestry got on the list with the ability to… well… consume trees… and speed their growth. Forestry explained Again, too much to explore in just two hours, but enticing enough to get me logged in early and ready to join the test once the world was opened.  We didn’t get to pick where we wanted to go, but I ended up on Zaraxa, the desert planet, which was good enough for me. Arrival time You may notice in the image above an in later images that everybody is no longer the default character model for the chosen race/sex, wearing the usual blue jumpsuit.  While character customization is not yet available to users, the team was testing the underlying customization tech and so was assigning us random looks whenever we arrived or went through a portal. I suspect that “random” was being used to indicate a pick from a selection of pre-sets, because I saw the same models rather frequently.  I started off as a male Elioni, the cat ears race, and got some middle age spread, wide hips, and some unflattering baggy trousers.  But the, so did other male Elioni I ran across. Fat cat camp dance off Likewise, I saw my share of Billy Bob Beergut Terran males.  Only the Gertan, the horned humanoids, seemed be be spared a “before” weight loss ad model.  I suspect somebody favors them on the dev team. Anyway, desert planet… pretty cool.  It did feel like a very different biome relative to the first planet, and had a number of locations that attracted the eye right away. I never made it to that, but I tried There was also a pyramid not so far off, though it was infested with hostile mobs. The ballhog mobs seem to live here I decided to be a landscape tourist and do a bit of surveying just to give me something that would guide me around.  The local mobs were a bit of an issue, though we had been warned that they might be. A prowler and two skysharks… also, stop looking at my ass… I’m working on it The prowlers were new, and persistent.  Somebody in chat said they had one follow them across the map. I ran around there for a while, then decided I wanted to see the jungle planet of Gaiamar.  The devs had nicely added a visible beacon to the portal locations, so I was able to find my way back.  There is no choosing a destination currently and the portals only connect two points.  So, to get to the jungle you first have to go to space and then find the appropriate portal on an asteroid to take you to your desired destination. I got into space okay, and didn’t even crash, but on going through the first portal I located there, I found myself embedded in a pillar in a location that was within the skybox but not on the play space of the world itself.  This is what Bhagpuss was referring to in his post about the test. Record scratch, freeze frame, “Yep, that’s me.” For once I am not cropping out the UI to just show the good bits, just to indicate that not only was I inside a pillar… unlike Lot’s wife, I wasn’t turned into a pillar of anything… but my health bars and tool slots were all empty.  I could not move or do anything in this corner of the world. This was a test, so I put this in chat so the devs could take a peek to figure out what was going on.  Somebody from the team showed up and told me I had somehow landed at the 0, 0, 0 coordinates for the world as they removed the pillar. There I am, pillar removed, new outfit, still thicc… and standing on a power up? They could not, however, move me from that location.  I spent some time moving the camera around while they figured things out. What the world looks like from the outside Eventually it was suggested that I just quit out and try to log back in.  However, that got me stuck at the loading screen with the message “World destination received, transporting you now!” on the loading screen, which just sat there. It seemed my character was toast.  That happens.  Things are in pre-alpha.  We’re here to find these sorts of things.  So I created a new character, a Terran male, and got the Billy Bob Beergut model I had seen a few times already. Starting to feel seen here… why don’t I ever get the hot bod like that guy? But I was back on the desert planet again.  So I headed to the portal… and crashed. Fancy new portal screen… with the crash notification I went to log back in and found that my Terran male was now also stuck with the “World destination received, transporting you now!” message on the loading screen.  Two characters down, time to make a third. Going down the list of my usual names Tistann was a male Gertan and at least looked fit.  He also made it through to space and then to the jungle planet successfully, so tourist mission accomplished… though there are jungles and there are jungles. Bananas, coconuts, and some bamboo out there somewhere I might have gone with “tropical” as the planet description, as jungle, at least in my mind, brings forth an image of considerably higher plant density.  And they had deemed the original planet “temperate,” so if we follow that pattern then the desert planet should probably have been “arid” as a description.  But that is just me trying to find consistent categories. By that point we were past the 90 minute mark of the test, so things were too far along to get much of anything accomplished.  I went back to the survey mission just to see the planet… and at least I had a decent body this time. Dancing with the cat peeps, look at this fit Gertan The survey mission took me all over the map, up and down, including into some higher altitude spots that led me through a frozen bamboo grove. Also, the place is loaded with hostile mobs Again, jungle or even tropical planet… going to need to tune the temperature gradients.  I mean, sure, it snows in Hawaii up on Mauna Kea… but that is some serious altitude. But I was out there running up and down the terrain looking for those survey points. I always spot the most distant ones Also, thanks to being outside of the world, I know those mountains in the distance are unreachable. The survey quest led me around to the inevitable lava area with survey points in the middle. Also, the inevitable draining of water into the lava I found a nice observation post up above the lava… not that it did anything other than give you a little building to stand in and look at the lava. Behold, lava… or magma… or whatever I suspect that was part of the world build.  I cannot recall having seen anything built by players with the civil engineering tools.  But then, I was running around the corners of the map surveying or stuck inside of a pillar for a lot of the time. There were at least three survey points in the lava.  I was able to slowly freeze my way out to one… though I had to mine for a bit to gain the points to unlock the freeze option on the ranger tool. For the second I ran into somebody else who needed it, so we did a bit of freeze co-op to get to it. A family that freezes together… or something By the time we got there the clock had run down to just five minutes or so left.  Raph was thinking about closing things out by destroying the world in a meteor shower, but was talked out of it so as to not require everybody to start again from scratch for the next play test. I ran around trying to scoop up the last few survey points, and got to 59 of 64.  I had unlocked the survey map by that point, having once again abandoned any thought of crafting the grav mesh, and following that I was led back around to the lava once more for the node I had missed.  I just ran out into the lava to see if I could snatch it. Lava walking… so hot right now Lava, and water, currently just act like the gaseous portions of the atmosphere as you can just walk right through them.  No need to learn to swim yet. After that we were done for the day.  I didn’t get a chance to go to the post-test fireside as I had to go help a boomer generation relative setup a new computer, something that dragged out into an all day and into the night affair.  Setting up an iMac is easy, moving files and settings from a 2009 iMac breaks things and put the new iMac in a state where it could only boot up in Safe Mode, followed by a hundred questions about what was going on even as I was literally Googling answers on my phone right in front of them, a clear indication that I was no expert on the situation.  I bought my last Macintosh in 1996. So an interesting test with new things to look into.  Yes there were problems, but as I always note, this is pre-alpha, nobody has paid for the game yet, we’re all here to help find problems while getting a peek at the early iterations of the game. There was, once again, people asking for longer test runs or even for the dev team to leave the game running overnight or for the course of a week, but the team demurred.  If they don’t feel it is there yet, if they are still getting better data from short focused test… though we were a bit unfocused this time around, and were never asked to all go do something specific… then that is where we’ll be for now. I suspect, if the blog is still going, the “Five Years Ago” section of the November 2029 in Review post will get me to thinking about how crazy this all was at the time and, one hopes, amazed at how far it has come since. Past play test posts for Stars Reach: Sep 17, 2024 – Stars Reach and the Terrain Modification Play Test Oct 7, 2024 – Scenes from a Stars Reach New Tools Play Test Oct 21, 2024 – Stars Reach and Play Testing Combat, Exploration, and Ranger Skills Nov 4, 2024 – Stars Reach Takes its Play Test into Space Nov 18, 2024 – Stars Reach: Jungle World, Desert World, and More Play Test Time
html:
I think it is a pretty good sign that I continue to feel that the 2 hour sessions are not enough time to even begin to explore the bounds of what the Stars Reach team has up for us on the play tests so far, and the test this past weekend only built on that feeling.

Stars Reach Announced

That said, I was in a bit of a mood going into the weekend’s test as I had been in a weekday session that was the same parameters as the last big weekend test and it did not go well for me.  I had decided I was going to figure out gathering resources and crafting, so as the test opened I headed straight to the portal and went into space to harvest resources, that being the easiest location… according to some… for a number critical materials.

Unfortunately right now there is a problem where, when mining through the crust of an asteroid, it is pretty easy to get yourself into an untenable state in a cave of hole and the game just declares you dead instantly.

Another asteroid mining death

That happened a half a dozen times to me in short order, including twice just trying to get close enough to my corpse to retrieve my stuff, such that I decided I needed a break from that.  As it was, my goal was to craft the grav mesh and you have to unlock the recipe, so I went back through the portal to collect survey locations to get enough points to unlock the recipe.  On doing that I found myself short on a couple of items and clearly needed to go back to space.

However, in the mean time somebody decided it would be great to turn the ground around the portal to lava so nobody could use it.

I said we’d get to this story, right?

Welcome to the sandbox.  I quit the game and went off to do something else at that point.  Some people are going to be jerks just because they can and I was already frustrated about all the asteroid mining deaths.

That feeling lingered and I considered giving Saturday a miss, however there was the promise of new things.  New things make pre-alpha fun.

The test notes indicated that the multiple planet test would now include multiple planets.  In addition to the temperate planet we had been testing on, Rodin IV so named, we would be getting a desert planet named Zaraxa and a jungle planet named Gaiamar.

Also, there would be some new stuff in the skill trees.

The skill trees available for the test

Those included civil engineers, which allowed for building things.

Civil Engineering

Also forestry got on the list with the ability to… well… consume trees… and speed their growth.

Forestry explained

Again, too much to explore in just two hours, but enticing enough to get me logged in early and ready to join the test once the world was opened.  We didn’t get to pick where we wanted to go, but I ended up on Zaraxa, the desert planet, which was good enough for me.

Arrival time

You may notice in the image above an in later images that everybody is no longer the default character model for the chosen race/sex, wearing the usual blue jumpsuit.  While character customization is not yet available to users, the team was testing the underlying customization tech and so was assigning us random looks whenever we arrived or went through a portal.

I suspect that “random” was being used to indicate a pick from a selection of pre-sets, because I saw the same models rather frequently.  I started off as a male Elioni, the cat ears race, and got some middle age spread, wide hips, and some unflattering baggy trousers.  But the, so did other male Elioni I ran across.

Fat cat camp dance off

Likewise, I saw my share of Billy Bob Beergut Terran males.  Only the Gertan, the horned humanoids, seemed be be spared a “before” weight loss ad model.  I suspect somebody favors them on the dev team.

Anyway, desert planet… pretty cool.  It did feel like a very different biome relative to the first planet, and had a number of locations that attracted the eye right away.

I never made it to that, but I tried

There was also a pyramid not so far off, though it was infested with hostile mobs.

The ballhog mobs seem to live here

I decided to be a landscape tourist and do a bit of surveying just to give me something that would guide me around.  The local mobs were a bit of an issue, though we had been warned that they might be.

A prowler and two skysharks… also, stop looking at my ass… I’m working on it

The prowlers were new, and persistent.  Somebody in chat said they had one follow them across the map.

I ran around there for a while, then decided I wanted to see the jungle planet of Gaiamar.  The devs had nicely added a visible beacon to the portal locations, so I was able to find my way back.  There is no choosing a destination currently and the portals only connect two points.  So, to get to the jungle you first have to go to space and then find the appropriate portal on an asteroid to take you to your desired destination.

I got into space okay, and didn’t even crash, but on going through the first portal I located there, I found myself embedded in a pillar in a location that was within the skybox but not on the play space of the world itself.  This is what Bhagpuss was referring to in his post about the test.

Record scratch, freeze frame, “Yep, that’s me.”

For once I am not cropping out the UI to just show the good bits, just to indicate that not only was I inside a pillar… unlike Lot’s wife, I wasn’t turned into a pillar of anything… but my health bars and tool slots were all empty.  I could not move or do anything in this corner of the world.

This was a test, so I put this in chat so the devs could take a peek to figure out what was going on.  Somebody from the team showed up and told me I had somehow landed at the 0, 0, 0 coordinates for the world as they removed the pillar.

There I am, pillar removed, new outfit, still thicc… and standing on a power up?

They could not, however, move me from that location.  I spent some time moving the camera around while they figured things out.

What the world looks like from the outside

Eventually it was suggested that I just quit out and try to log back in.  However, that got me stuck at the loading screen with the message “World destination received, transporting you now!” on the loading screen, which just sat there.

It seemed my character was toast.  That happens.  Things are in pre-alpha.  We’re here to find these sorts of things.  So I created a new character, a Terran male, and got the Billy Bob Beergut model I had seen a few times already.

Starting to feel seen here… why don’t I ever get the hot bod like that guy?

But I was back on the desert planet again.  So I headed to the portal… and crashed.

Fancy new portal screen… with the crash notification

I went to log back in and found that my Terran male was now also stuck with the “World destination received, transporting you now!” message on the loading screen.  Two characters down, time to make a third.

Going down the list of my usual names

Tistann was a male Gertan and at least looked fit.  He also made it through to space and then to the jungle planet successfully, so tourist mission accomplished… though there are jungles and there are jungles.

Bananas, coconuts, and some bamboo out there somewhere

I might have gone with “tropical” as the planet description, as jungle, at least in my mind, brings forth an image of considerably higher plant density.  And they had deemed the original planet “temperate,” so if we follow that pattern then the desert planet should probably have been “arid” as a description.  But that is just me trying to find consistent categories.

By that point we were past the 90 minute mark of the test, so things were too far along to get much of anything accomplished.  I went back to the survey mission just to see the planet… and at least I had a decent body this time.

Dancing with the cat peeps, look at this fit Gertan

The survey mission took me all over the map, up and down, including into some higher altitude spots that led me through a frozen bamboo grove.

Also, the place is loaded with hostile mobs

Again, jungle or even tropical planet… going to need to tune the temperature gradients.  I mean, sure, it snows in Hawaii up on Mauna Kea… but that is some serious altitude.

But I was out there running up and down the terrain looking for those survey points.

I always spot the most distant ones

Also, thanks to being outside of the world, I know those mountains in the distance are unreachable.

The survey quest led me around to the inevitable lava area with survey points in the middle.

Also, the inevitable draining of water into the lava

I found a nice observation post up above the lava… not that it did anything other than give you a little building to stand in and look at the lava.

Behold, lava… or magma… or whatever

I suspect that was part of the world build.  I cannot recall having seen anything built by players with the civil engineering tools.  But then, I was running around the corners of the map surveying or stuck inside of a pillar for a lot of the time.

There were at least three survey points in the lava.  I was able to slowly freeze my way out to one… though I had to mine for a bit to gain the points to unlock the freeze option on the ranger tool.

For the second I ran into somebody else who needed it, so we did a bit of freeze co-op to get to it.

A family that freezes together… or something

By the time we got there the clock had run down to just five minutes or so left.  Raph was thinking about closing things out by destroying the world in a meteor shower, but was talked out of it so as to not require everybody to start again from scratch for the next play test.

I ran around trying to scoop up the last few survey points, and got to 59 of 64.  I had unlocked the survey map by that point, having once again abandoned any thought of crafting the grav mesh, and following that I was led back around to the lava once more for the node I had missed.  I just ran out into the lava to see if I could snatch it.

Lava walking… so hot right now

Lava, and water, currently just act like the gaseous portions of the atmosphere as you can just walk right through them.  No need to learn to swim yet.

After that we were done for the day.  I didn’t get a chance to go to the post-test fireside as I had to go help a boomer generation relative setup a new computer, something that dragged out into an all day and into the night affair.  Setting up an iMac is easy, moving files and settings from a 2009 iMac breaks things and put the new iMac in a state where it could only boot up in Safe Mode, followed by a hundred questions about what was going on even as I was literally Googling answers on my phone right in front of them, a clear indication that I was no expert on the situation.  I bought my last Macintosh in 1996.

So an interesting test with new things to look into.  Yes there were problems, but as I always note, this is pre-alpha, nobody has paid for the game yet, we’re all here to help find problems while getting a peek at the early iterations of the game.

There was, once again, people asking for longer test runs or even for the dev team to leave the game running overnight or for the course of a week, but the team demurred.  If they don’t feel it is there yet, if they are still getting better data from short focused test… though we were a bit unfocused this time around, and were never asked to all go do something specific… then that is where we’ll be for now.

I suspect, if the blog is still going, the “Five Years Ago” section of the November 2029 in Review post will get me to thinking about how crazy this all was at the time and, one hopes, amazed at how far it has come since.

  • Oct 7, 2024 – Scenes from a Stars Reach New Tools Play Test

  • Nov 4, 2024 – Stars Reach Takes its Play Test into Space
